subject: Re: [junit] Re: Component testing
msgSnippet: ... A unit test is whatever you want it to be. I am told that the IEEE definition of unit is so vague as to be useless. Since I program mainly in OO
messageBody:
Jagmohan S Nanaware wrote:

> Hi,
>
> Got it! Thanks.
>
> One more basic question.
>
> How is unit testing different from component testing.
> Let me clarify. Here the component is not something
> like COM, but a set of C functions with some exposed
> APIs. Testing includes testing these interfaces and
> functionality implemented by this component through
> these set of C functions.

A unit test is whatever you want it to be. I am told that the IEEE
definition of "unit" is so vague as to be useless.

Since I program mainly in OO languages, I test objects. That means that
I fix one object (class) to test, then simulate all its collaborators. I
only test one object at a time. If you have a group of functions that
all operate on a common parameter, then they are /essentially/ the same
as methods on a class, and so testing those functions by simulating
every other function they might invoke constitutes object testing.

I occasionally test multiple objects at once. When I do, this is
integration testing: writing a test that exercises multiple
production-quality objects collaborating with one another. If you test a
function and allow it to invoke the real implementations of the other
functions it uses, then I call that integration testing.

I /suppose/ that if a component is an implementation of a single
interface, /and/ if you simulate any of the other components with which
it collaborates, then testing that component would be equivalent to
object testing.

> Currently the way I test these by writing some test
> stubs. If it is advantageous to move to cppunit/junit
> I would love to do so. Please note that the developer
> of these components is not me.

Since you're working in C, you might want to just start with this:

TestDriver.c

int main(int argc, char** argv) {
void* result = invokeYourFunction(parameter1, parameter2);
if (compare(expectedResult, result) != 0) {
return -1;
}

return 0;
}

This is a simple test driver that tries to invoke one of your functions
with a set of inputs and returns a result. It then compares the result
to the result you expect, "failing" if they don't match and "passing" if
they do. Write your first test in a similar way. Then another. Then
another. Refactor out the common bits of the test driver. After about
ten tests you'll have a fully working framework of your own to use and love.

That is, of course, if there's no good C-Unit implementation. Maybe
there is. Ask Google.
